on I-90, it is rapidly growing due to the recent upsurge in oil and gas drilling.
Gillette is a coal mining town with a population of about 30,000.

Located between the Black Hills of South Dakota and Yellowstone National Park, Gillette is an excellent place to stop if you are travelling I-90 East or West. Highway 59 connects the town with Montana to the north and Douglas, WY to the south.

Gillette–Campbell County Airport has non-stop service on Delta to Rock Springs and Salt Lake City and United to Denver.
Simple town layout. Use your phone or ask a local (they are very friendly!).

Free coal mine tours in the summer time. The Rockpile Museum is an excellent free historical museum. There is a heavy equipment park near the CAM-PLEX multi-events center and a coal mine overlook just north of town on Highway 14-16.
Coal mine tours, Rockpile Museum, 2 frisbee golf courses, free city pool, Rec Center, AVA Art Center, CAM-PLEX events, etc.
There's a Walmart. More shops are in nearby

Best local (non-chain) restaurants: If you are traveling on Highway 59, just south of Gillette there is a little Cafe called Roberto's which is not even on Google Maps. Simple, cheap, delicious Mexican and American food EXTREMELY friendly waitress. (I mention this because you probably won't hear it anywhere else.) Other good eats: Humphrey's Bar and Grill has a wide selection of beer, big portions for lunch and dinner and a few unique food creations, Mufa (yes that's the name)Cafe has a delicious pancake bar with oatmeal pancakes and all the toppings you can pile on. Avoid: Skyline Grill.

value: directions=From I-90 take exit 128, go west ½ mile.

The Green Tree's Crazy Woman Campground is an interesting place to stay. Free WIFI, trees, hot tub, and sauna.

value: directions=From I-90 take exit 128, go west ½ mile
price=$49.59, kids 12 and under free, pets $7 pet

content=Amenities include large cable TV, daily newspaper, guest business center, room service, 24 hour coffee bar, outdoor heated pool (seasonal), high speed internet, in-room microwave and refrigerator.  Restaurant, lounge.

The Gillette Convention and Visitor's Bureau is the best place for information. They are located in the parking lot of the Flying J on Hwy 59 just off of Exit 126.

If you are headed East be sure to visit Devil's Tower National Park on your way into the Black Hills. Mount Rushmoore is over-rated, but Custer State Park, the Needles Highway, and the various caves of the Black Hills are all worth checking out.

If you are headed west take 16 on into Yellowstone. Watch out for buffalo!
